ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Strengths: approachable professors, good foundation in current parasitological research on select topicsWeaknesses: feedback given too late for improvement on subsequent writing assignments (and question marks were not helpful -- more specific/tailored, longer responses would be very helpful!); lectures on parasitic organisms could be more basic (i.e. more lifecycle explanation such as what cercariae are, etc. -- I had no idea what organisms looked like, many major symptoms of diseases, and basic types of hosts (paratenic, etc.) were from taking the course; I felt that I knew a lot about RNAi and other inducible systems/select new research on particular parasitic systems, but very little about general interventions currently taken for parasitic organisms, which was disappointing)

excellent course. i learned very valuable skills for research while studying organisms that i had never looked at through this lens. although the workload was more than most other courses, i felt it was appropriate and that i was getting exactly what i needed.
The topics covered in the course were very interesting but the weekly assignments were tedious and sometimes unnecessary.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Very friendly; could be more formal in lecturing (see above: more background, less jokes); could be faster and more specific in feedback
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  always a pleasure, loves his work and it shows.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Dr. Tschudi gave very interesting lectures and made the course memorable.

Instructor: Diane McMahon-Pratt  Again, approachable; good with most written feedback; can be intimidating, particularly when discussing Chemistry (as sometimes assumes that students follow particular terms like Km or dissociation constants or Balb/c mice, without discussing what these particular terms or ideas are, especially during presentation discussions and early lectures)
Instructor: Diane McMahon-Pratt  again, a wonderful instructor who loves her work. her input in discussions across other neglected tropical diseases and methodologies was also very helpful.
Instructor: Diane McMahon-Pratt  Dr. Pratt gave very interesting lectures and made the course memorable.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this to a biomedical science student looking to survey particular parasitic research systems, but not to any student in more general public health or to any student without a desire to tear apart biomedical research. So -- to a few students, the course might be helpful -- to others, its probably a combination of overwhelming, sometimes quite boring, and sometimes frustrating.
if you want to learn an important part of research, take this course.
I would recommend this course to another student
